sentence1_translated: Mo gbọ́ pé ó sọ ọ́ lọ́nà tó ṣe kedere.

sentence1: But laugh though he might, he knew as well as Pitt that in going ashore that morning he carried his life in his hands.
sentence1_translated: Àmọ́ bó ti wù kó máa rẹ́rìn-ín, ó mọ̀ bíi ti Pitt pé bó ṣe lọ sí etíkun lọ́sàn-án yẹn ló mú kí òun gbé ìgbésí ayé òun.

sentence1: I... I had not dreamed....
sentence1_translated: Mi ò rí i rí...

sentence1: But there is no hope for him in that!  she cried.
sentence1_translated: Àmọ́ kò sí ìrètí kankan fún un nínú èyí!

sentence1: I will take leave to doubt it.  His lordship's tone abated nothing of its asperity.
sentence1_translated: Mo gbà láti ṣiyèméjì nípa rẹ̀.

sentence1: There was here quite plainly a vague threat, a mutinous spirit he could not understand.
sentence1_translated: Ó ṣe kedere pé ewu kan wà tó ń ba òun lẹ́rù, ìyẹn ni ẹ̀mí ìdìtẹ̀ tó ò lè lóye.

sentence1: Don't be forgetting that.   Jeremy clenched his hands.
sentence1_translated: Má gbàgbé pé, Jeremy fọwọ́ kan ara rẹ̀.

sentence1: But it gave no pause to the gunner's intention.
sentence1_translated: Àmọ́, kò sí ohun tó mú kí ohun tó fẹ́ ṣe yẹn súni.

sentence1: But Blood's mind was now made up.
sentence1_translated: Àmọ́, ohun tí Ẹ̀jẹ̀ sọ ti wá di ìpinnu.

sentence1: Why, as I was just telling his lordship here, who thought like you that having Miss Bishop aboard would make us safe, not for his mother would that filthy slaver forgo what's due to him.
sentence1_translated: Bí mo ṣe ń sọ fún Ọ̀gá mi yìí, ẹni tó rò bíi tìẹ pé tí Miss Bishop bá wà nínú ọkọ̀ á mú ká láìséwu, kì í ṣe nítorí ìyá rẹ̀ ni ẹrú burúkú yẹn á fi ohun tó yẹ fún un sílẹ̀.

sentence1: In his cabin on the starboard side Lord Julian, disturbed by the same sounds, was already astir and hurriedly dressing.
sentence1_translated: Nínú ilé rẹ̀ tó wà ní apá ọ̀tún, ọ̀gágun Julian, tí àwọn ohùn náà ń ru òun lọ́kàn sókè, ti ń múra lọ́nà tó ń kánjú.

sentence1: Let me present Captain Blood.   Perforce Bishop must put on the best face he could command.
sentence1_translated: Ẹ jẹ́ kí n sọ fún yín pé, kí ó lè ṣe gbogbo ohun tó lè ṣe láti mú kí Bishop ṣe ojú rere.

sentence1: Pitt, at his post beside the helmsman, turned intrepidly to face the excited gunner.
sentence1_translated: Pitt, tó wà nípò rẹ̀ nítòsí olórí ọkọ̀ náà, yíjú láìbẹ̀rù sí ẹni tó ń fi ìbọn gun náà.

sentence1: Blood leaned over the rail to speak to the fair young man immediately below him by the helmsman at the whipstaff.
sentence1_translated: Ẹ̀jẹ̣ náà tẹ̀ lé òpó igi láti bá ọ̀dọ́kùnrin tó wà nísàlẹ̀ rẹ̀ sọ̀rọ̣.

sentence1: The country is all, sir; the sovereign naught.
sentence1_translated: Ilẹ̀ ni gbogbo nǹkan, ọ̀gá mi; kò sí nǹkan kan tó lè ṣàkóso.

sentence1: His hand closed over the butt of one of the pistols slung before him.
sentence1_translated: Ó fi ọwọ́ rẹ̀ dì mọ́ ọlá ọta kan tó wà níwájú rẹ̀.

sentence1: It gives him a grievance at last.
sentence1_translated: Ó wá di pé ó ní ìkùnsínú.

sentence1: Wait!  Blood bade him, interrupting, and he set a restraining hand upon the gunner's arm.
sentence1_translated: Ẹ̀jẹ̣ sọ fún un pé kó lọ, ó sì dá a dúró, ó sì fi ọwọ́ rẹ̀ sí apá tó ń fi ìbọn ṣe nǹkan.

sentence1: And for all that he lost nothing of his outward stern composure, fear invaded his heart.
sentence1_translated: Bó tilẹ̀ jẹ́ pé kò ní ìrẹ̀wẹ̀sì kankan, ìbẹ̀rù wá wọ ọkàn rẹ̀.

sentence1: Through her and through you.
sentence1_translated: Ó ń ṣe é nípasẹ̀ rẹ àti nípasẹ̀ rẹ.

sentence1: Though we had a cargo of Bishop's nieces it wouldn't make him hold his hand.
sentence1_translated: Bó tilẹ̀ jẹ́ pé a ní àwọn ọmọ àbúrò Bishop, kò ní jẹ́ kó rí ọwọ́ rẹ̀ mú.

sentence1: If now he can show that....
sentence1_translated: Tó bá ti lè fi hàn báyìí pé...

sentence1: That is what we were advised.
sentence1_translated: Ohun tí wọ́n sọ fún wa nìyẹn.

sentence1: How?  she asked him with a sudden startled interest.
sentence1_translated: Ó béèrè lọ́wọ́ rẹ̀ lọ́nà tó fi hàn pé òun nífẹ̀ẹ́ sí ọ̀rọ̀ náà gan-an.

sentence1: ‘Twill be a kindness, so it will.   For a moment she stood before him with quickened breathing, the colour ebbing and flowing in her cheeks.
sentence1_translated: Ó sì dúró níwájú rẹ̀ fún ìgbà kan, ó sì ń mí ẹ̀mí, àwọ̀ náà sì ń ṣàn nínú ẹ̀yà rẹ̀.

sentence1: He was moved to raise his voice above its usual languid level.
sentence1_translated: Ó wá sọ pé òun fẹ́ láti gbé ohùn òun ga ju bó ṣe máa ń ṣe tẹ́lẹ̀ lọ.

sentence1: My name is Wade--Lord Julian Wade.
sentence1_translated: Orúkọ mi ni Wade, Ọ̀gá Julian Wade.

sentence1: I see, sir, that you do not yet quite apprehend the circumstances.
sentence1_translated: Mo rí i, ọ̀gá mi, pé o ò tíì lóye àwọn ohun tó ń ṣẹlẹ̀.

sentence1: I am pressed,  she informed him.
sentence1_translated: Ó sọ fún un pé, ó ń ṣe mí láṣeyọrí.

sentence1: As for me,  said Lord Julian, with intent to make Miss Bishop's departure free from all interference on the part of the buccaneers,  I shall remain aboard the Arabella until we reach Port Royal.
sentence1_translated: Bí mo ṣe ń lọ, Lord Julian sọ pé, kí ìlọ̀ ti Miss Bishop lè bọ́ lọ́wọ́ gbogbo ìnira látọ̀dọ̀ àwọn tó ń rìnrìn àjò lọ, èmi yóò dúró lórí ọkọ̀ òkun Arabella títí a ó fi dé Port Royal.

sentence1: Then:   You ordered it?  he said in accents of unbelief, whilst Lord Julian raised his eyebrows.
sentence1_translated: Ó wá sọ pé: "Ìwọ ló pa á láṣẹ?" Ó sì sọ ní tààràtà pé: "Ẹ̀yin ni ó pa á láṣẹ".

sentence1: Expressly.   His lordship waited a moment for a reply.
sentence1_translated: Ó ní kí ọ̀gá rẹ̀ dúró fún ìdáhùn.

sentence1: You know, Peter, that it is Lord Julian alone has stood between Bishop and his hate of you.
sentence1_translated: O mọ̀, Peter, pé kìkì Lord Julian nìkan ló wà láàárín Bishop àti ìkórìíra tó ní sí ọ.

sentence1: But many could not resolve one way or the other until they were satisfied upon several questions, and chiefly upon one which was voiced by Ogle.
sentence1_translated: Àmọ́ ọ̀pọ̀ èèyàn ò lè yanjú ọ̀ràn náà lọ́nà kan tàbí òmíràn títí dìgbà tí wọ́n bá ti rí ìdáhùn sí ọ̀pọ̀ ìbéèrè, pàápàá jù lọ ìbéèrè kan tí Ogle sọ.

sentence1: Ye're going to deliver yourself into Bishop's hands,  Pitt warned him.
sentence1_translated: Pitt kìlọ̀ fún un pé, wàá fi ara rẹ lé Bishop lọ́wọ́.

sentence1: Standing beside Captain Blood, he looked astern, following the indication of the Captain's hand, and cried out in his amazement.
sentence1_translated: O duro lẹgbẹẹ Captain Blood, o wo lẹhin, tẹle awọn itọkasi ti awọn Captain ká ọwọ, o si kigbe ni rẹ iyalẹnu.

sentence1: He may be right, and he may be wrong.
sentence1_translated: Ó lè jẹ́ pé ó tọ́, ó sì lè jẹ́ pé ó ṣi ẹ̀tàn.

sentence1: But if she resented his tone and his words, she stifled her resentment.
sentence1_translated: Àmọ́, tó bá ń ṣe ohun tó ń sọ, tó sì ń sọ ọ̀rọ̀ tó ń sọ, ńṣe ló máa ń fi ìbínú rẹ̀ pa á.

sentence1: I am informed that yesterday evening a frigate left the harbour having on board your associate Wolverstone and a hundred men of the hundred and fifty that were serving under you.
sentence1_translated: A ti sọ fún mi pé lálẹ́ ọjọ́ kẹ́yìn, ọkọ̀ ojú omi kan kúrò ní ìbúté, ó ní Wolverstone àti ọgọ́rùn-ún ọkùnrin nínú ọgọ́rùn-ún márùn-ún tí wọ́n ń sìn lábẹ́ rẹ.

sentence1: And instantly would have recalled the words had she been able.
sentence1_translated: Ó sì máa rántí àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ náà lójú ẹsẹ̀ tó bá lè ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀.

sentence1: But that it was no more than a mask for his fury and his venom was plain to all.
sentence1_translated: Àmọ́, ńṣe ló dà bí àṣíborí fún ìbínú rẹ̀ àti bí èéfín rẹ̀ ṣe hàn kedere fún gbogbo èèyàn.

sentence1: Levasseur?  He smiled a little.
sentence1_translated: Ó rẹ́rìn-ín músẹ́ díẹ̀.

sentence1: HOSTILITIES   In the great harbour of Port Royal, spacious enough to have given moorings to all the ships of all the navies of the world, the Arabella rode at anchor.
sentence1_translated: NÍ Ìlú Port Royal, tó jẹ́ àgbègbè tó tóbi gan-an tó sì jẹ́ pé gbogbo ọkọ̀ òkun tó wà nínú gbogbo àwọn ẹgbẹ́ ọmọ ogun òkun ayé ló ti ń wọlé, ọkọ̀ òkun Arabella náà ń gun àkọ̀.

sentence1: He swung to Lord Julian.
sentence1_translated: Ó wá bá Ọ̀gá Julian.

sentence1: Good-morning to you,  he said, and added  I've blundered badly, so I have.
sentence1_translated: Ó sọ pé, "Ìrọ̀lẹ́ mi o, mo sì tún sọ pé, mo ti ṣe àṣìṣe ńlá, torí náà mo ṣe é.

sentence1: He stepped back, a baffled, impotent man.
sentence1_translated: Ó dá sí i, ó dà bí ẹni tí kò mọ ohun tó lè ṣe, kò sì lè ṣe nǹkan kan.

sentence1: Although even some o' they should know better, for there's still a few was on Barbados with us, and are acquainted like me and you with Colonel Bishop.
sentence1_translated: Bó tilẹ̀ jẹ́ pé àwọn kan pàápàá ní láti mọ̀ dáadáa, nítorí pé àwọn kan ṣì wà lórílẹ̀-èdè Barbados pẹ̀lú wa, wọ́n sì mọ̀ nípa Alàgbà Bishop bíi tèmi àti tìẹ.

sentence1: Pitt, loosely clad in shirt and breeches, leaned against the rail the while and watched him, unmistakable concern imprinted on his fair, frank countenance.
sentence1_translated: Pitt, loosely wọ aṣọ ati burs, gbọn si awọn rail nigba ti o si wo o, unmistakable aibalẹ ti imprinted lori rẹ fair, frank oju.

sentence1: That'll be the signal to lie to,  said Blood, in the same listless voice; and he fetched a sigh.
sentence1_translated: Ti o yoo jẹ awọn ifihan lati tan si, wi Ẹjẹ, ni awọn kanna alaigbọwọ ohùn; o si mu a sigh.

sentence1: And what better are these?--Are ye afeard of a lubberly Barbados planter? Whatever ails you, Peter? I've never known ye scared afore.   A gun boomed out behind them.
sentence1_translated: Ati ohun ti o dara ju awọn wọnyi ni? - Ṣe o bẹru ti a lubberly Barbados planter? Ohun ti o ba ti o, Peter? Mo ti ko mọ o ti bẹru ṣaaju ki o to. a gun boomed jade lẹhin wọn.

sentence1: And a couple of miles this side of it, bearing after them, came speeding three great white ships.
sentence1_translated: Àwọn ọkọ̀ òkun funfun ńlá mẹ́ta ń sáré lẹ́yìn wọn.

sentence1: It's our only chance, I've said, and we must take it.   The better way that was in Captain Blood's mind was the way that already he had proposed to Wolverstone.
sentence1_translated: Mo sọ pé, àǹfààní wa nìkan ni, a sì gbọ́dọ̀ lò ó, nítorí pé ọ̀nà tó dára jù lọ tí ọ̀gágun Blood gbà ronú ni èyí tó ti sọ fún Wolverstone pé kó lọ.

sentence1: The young master's grey eyes skimmed it.
sentence1_translated: Àwọn ojú awọ ọ̀dọ́ ọ̀gá náà fi hàn pé kò rí nǹkan kan.

sentence1: Whether the men in the panic Ogle had aroused among them would take a different view from Wolverstone's he did not know.
sentence1_translated: Bóyá àwọn ọkùnrin tí Ogle ti mú kí wọ́n panicked láàárín wọn yóò gba ojú tó yàtọ̀ sí Wolverstone ká kò mọ.

sentence1: Heave her to, and signal to them to send a boat.   A silence of astonishment fell upon the ship--of astonishment and suspicion at this sudden yielding.
sentence1_translated: Fi i soke si, ki o si fi agbara si wọn lati rán ọkọ oju omi kan. a ọ̀rọ̀ ìyanu ti ṣubu lori ọkọ oju omi - ti ìyanu ati fura si yi lojiji fifun.

sentence1: I accept it as the only way to save us all from the certain destruction into which my own act may have brought us.
sentence1_translated: Mo gbà pé ọ̀nà kan ṣoṣo ni láti gbà gbà gbà wá là kúrò nínú ìparun tí mo ti ṣe.

sentence1: I... I can't think why you should speak to me like this,  she said, with less than her earlier assurance.
sentence1_translated: Ó sọ pé, òun ò lè ronú pé kí òun máa bá òun sọ̀rọ̀ lọ́nà yìí, òun ò sì ní fi irú ìdánilójú tó ní ṣáájú òun yìí hàn.

sentence1: And the quixotic fool is running into danger at the present moment on our behalf.
sentence1_translated: Àní, òmùgọ̀ tó ń ṣe àdàkàdekè yìí ń bá a jà nísinsìnyí.

sentence1: A thin, sour smile broke on the officer's haughty lips.
sentence1_translated: Ìwọ náà sì rí i pé ńṣe ni ọ̀rọ̀ rẹ̀ ń dùn ún gan-an.

sentence1: So that ye can be charitable in some ways!  He laughed softly.
sentence1_translated: Ó rẹ́rìn-ín pẹ̀lú ìrẹ̀lẹ̀.

sentence1: Hark to the gentleman!  he mocked.
sentence1_translated: Ó ń fi ọ̀rọ̀ náà ṣe yẹ̀yẹ́.

sentence1: Threats will not serve, Captain.
sentence1_translated: Ìbẹ̀rù kò ní lè ṣe wá láǹfààní, Àgùntàn.

sentence1: Captain Blood's glance raked the ranks of those resolute, fierce-eyed fellows, then it came to rest again on Ogle.
sentence1_translated: Ojú tí Àgùntàn Ẹ̀jẹ́ fi wò àwọn ọmọkùnrin tó ní ojú tó lágbára yìí tún wá sí Ogle.

sentence1: If ye're counting on pulling Bishop's heartstrings, ye're a bigger fool, Ogle, than I've always thought you was with anything but guns.
sentence1_translated: Tó o bá ń retí pé kí Bishop máa fi ọ̀pá ìnira rẹ̀ pa ẹ́, o ò ní lè ṣe ohun tó o rò, Ogle, àmọ́ o ti ní ìbọn.

sentence1: He had found the only way, and repellent though it might be to him, he must take it.
sentence1_translated: Ó ti rí ọ̀nà kan ṣoṣo, bó tilẹ̀ jẹ́ pé ó lè mú kó ṣòro fún un láti gbà á, ó gbọ́dọ̀ gbà á.

sentence1: He threw them at me again and again.
sentence1_translated: Ó tún ń fi wọ́n lé mi lọ́kàn léraléra.

sentence1: That is: that he has been notified of the coming of Lord Julian Wade.
sentence1_translated: Ó ní: ó ti gbọ́ nípa bí Lord Julian Wade ṣe ń dé.

sentence1: Oh, please.  There was real alarm in her voice.
sentence1_translated: Ó ní ìkìlọ̀ gidi nínú ohùn rẹ̀.

sentence1: Fearing to betray the latter, she took refuge in the former.
sentence1_translated: Ó bẹ̀rù pé òun máa tàbùkù sí òun, ó sì wá sá di òun.

sentence1: You take that tone! You dare to take that tone!  she cried, astounding him by her sudden vehemence.
sentence1_translated: Ó sunkún, ó sì fi ìtara tó ní hàn án lójijì.

sentence1: You may have heard of me.   Captain Calverley stared hard.
sentence1_translated: Ó ṣeé ṣe kó o ti gbọ́ nípa mi, àmọ́, ọ̀gágun Calverley ń wojú mi dáadáa.

sentence1: It isn't that.   But they were fated to misunderstand each other.
sentence1_translated: Kò ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀, àmọ́ ó ti pinnu pé wọn ò ní lóye ara wọn.

sentence1: If anything should happen to you, Peter,  he said, as Blood was going over the side,  Colonel Bishop had better look to himself.
sentence1_translated: Bí nǹkan bá ṣẹlẹ̀ sí ẹ, Peter, ó sọ pé bí ẹ̀jẹ̀ ṣe ń lọ sí òdìkejì, kí Olùkọ̀ọ́ Bishop máa wò ara rẹ̀ dáadáa.

sentence1: I'll be getting my hat and cane and sword, and go ashore in the cock-boat.
sentence1_translated: Èmi yóò kó àṣíborí mi àti ọ̀pá àti idà mi, kí n sì lọ sí etíkun nínú ọkọ̀ ojú omi.

sentence1: I must return to Colonel Bishop for my orders,  he informed them.
sentence1_translated: Ó sọ fún wọn pé kí n padà lọ bá Alàgbà Bishop fún àṣẹ mi.

sentence1: In a flash Captain Blood saw what was in their minds.
sentence1_translated: Lójú ẹ̀ṣẹ̀ kan, Àgùntàn Ẹ̀jẹ̀ rí ohun tí wọ́n ń rò.

sentence1: I do my best,  said she.
sentence1_translated: Ó sọ pé mo máa ń ṣe gbogbo ohun tí mo lè ṣe.

sentence1: Oh, but--by your leave--surely there is nothing to be apprehended from Colonel Bishop.
sentence1_translated: Ó, ṣùgbọ́n - nípa ìyọ́nú rẹ - dájúdájú kò sí ohun tí a lè fi ọwọ́ mú kúrò lọ́wọ́ Alàgbà Bishop.

sentence1: I wonder, now,  he said presently,  if the mischief is of your working.
sentence1_translated: Ó ní: "Mo máa ń ronú pé, ṣé iṣẹ́ tìẹ ló ń fa ìṣòro náà?

sentence1: Shrewd advocacy,  he approved it.
sentence1_translated: Ó fọwọ́ sí ọ̀rọ̀ tó ń gbéni ró.

sentence1: I have something to show you.   Wondering, Lord Julian mounted the companion as he was bidden.
sentence1_translated: Mo ní ohun kan láti fi hàn yín, bí Lord Julian ṣe ń gun ọkọ̀ náà gẹ́gẹ́ bí a ti pàṣẹ fún un.

sentence1: Before we've run another half-mile we shall be within range.   Wolverstone swore elaborately, then suddenly checked.
sentence1_translated: Ká tó fi máa sáré ìdajì mílíọ̀nù mìíràn, a ó ti wà ní àárín ìlà.

sentence1: He's chivalrous to the point of idiocy.
sentence1_translated: Ó máa ń ṣe àwọn nǹkan tó ń mú kí wọ́n máa hùwà òmùgọ̀.

sentence1: He levelled his telescope upon that figure.
sentence1_translated: Ó gbé ìràwọ̀ náà sójú àpáta.

sentence1: Miss Bishop was aboard the Royal Mary also, and I rescued her together with his lordship.
sentence1_translated: Miss Bishop wà ní àárín Royal Mary, mo sì gbà á là pẹ̀lú Ọ̀gá rẹ̀.

sentence1: What if he can?  Blood interrupted carelessly.
sentence1_translated: Bí ẹ̀jẹ̀ bá ti ń rúbọ láìfọ̀rọ̀ sábẹ́ ahọ́n, kí ló máa ṣẹlẹ̀?

sentence1: I'll rot in hell or ever I serves the King,  he bawled in a great rage.
sentence1_translated: Èmi yóò run nínú ọ̀run àpáàdì tàbí kí n máa sìn ọba, ó ń bú nínú ìbínú ńlá.

sentence1: Ye're surely daft even to think of it, Peter!
sentence1_translated: Ó dájú pé òmùgọ̀ lò ń ṣe, Peter!

sentence1: Standing now at the rail, with Lord Julian beside him, Captain Blood explained himself.
sentence1_translated: Nígbà tí Ọ̀gágun Ẹ̀jẹ̀ dúró lẹ́gbẹ̀ẹ́ rẹ̀, ó ṣàlàyé ara rẹ̀.

sentence1: A boat that had approached unnoticed from the shore came scraping and bumping against the great red hull of the Arabella, and a raucous voice sent up a hailing shout.
sentence1_translated: Òkun kan tó sún mọ́ òkun láìṣe akiyesi wá, ó sì ń kọlu ara òkun aláwọ̀ pupa tó wà ní òkun náà, ohùn kan sì ń pariwo.

sentence1: Ye'll remember afterwards that it was your hardness drove me.   She moved to depart, then checked, and faced him again.
sentence1_translated: O ó rántí nígbà tó yá pé ìwà ipá rẹ ló mú kí n lọ, ó sì tún gbé mi lọ.

sentence1: Faith, you explain yourself after a fashion,  said he.
sentence1_translated: Faith, ó sọ pé, o máa ń ṣàlàyé ara rẹ lọ́nà tó bá ti yẹ.

sentence1: A drinker of blood, he is.
sentence1_translated: Ó máa ń mu ẹ̀jẹ̀.

sentence1: It's the truth, you fool.
sentence1_translated: Òtítọ́ ni, òmùgọ̀.

sentence1: Heave to, Captain, and signal them to send a boat, and assure themselves that Miss is here.
sentence1_translated: Ẹ gbé ẹ̀rù yín sókè, kábíńtánì, kí ẹ sì fi àmì ránṣẹ́ ọkọ̀ ojú omi kan, kí ẹ sì mú un dá ara yín lójú pé Miss ti dé.

sentence1: And if ye' weren't a fool, Ogle, you wouldn't need me to tell you this.
sentence1_translated: Ká ní o kò ní jẹ́ òmùgọ̀, Ogle, o ò ní nílò mi láti sọ èyí fún ọ.

sentence1: And what should be happening to me, Jeremy? Sure, now, I'll be back for dinner, so I will.   Blood climbed down into the waiting boat.
sentence1_translated: Ó dájú pé, ní báyìí, màá pa dà wá jẹun, nítorí náà, ẹ̀jẹ̀ ti wọ inú ọkọ̀ ojú omi tó ń dúró.

sentence1: Just within the doorway of the alley leading to the cabin, he ran into Miss Bishop.
sentence1_translated: Ó rí ọ̀dọ́bìnrin Bishop ní ẹnu ọ̀nà tó ń lọ sí ilé.

sentence1: Ogle,  said he, in a voice cold and sharp as steel,  your station is on the gun-deck.
sentence1_translated: Ó ní, Ogle, ní ohùn tó tutù tó sì ń mú kí ọ̀rọ̀ rẹ rí bíi ti àwo, pé ibùdó rẹ wà lórí ìkọ̀kọ̀.

sentence1: Yet she had not been coming out, for her back was towards him, and she was moving in the same direction.
sentence1_translated: Sibẹsibẹ o ti wa ni ko ti wa ni jade, fun awọn ẹhin rẹ wà si o, o si ti n gbe ni ọna kanna.

sentence1: The museum is not strong on catalogues or labels
sentence1_translated: Àwòrán àti àkọlé tí ilé ìkọ́lé náà ń lò kò dára

sentence1: You can see beluga whales in summer, polar bears in the autumn, and, if you're around at the spring or autumn equinox, the  northern lights  of the aurora borealis.
sentence1_translated: O lè rí àwọn ẹyẹ bílúgà ní ìgbà ẹ̀ẹ̀rùn, ẹyẹ ẹyẹ ẹyẹ ẹyẹ amọ̀ ní ìgbà ìrúwé, àti, tó o bá wà ní àgbègbè ìrọ̀lẹ́ ọjọ́ ọ̀sán tàbí ìgbà ìrúwé, ìmọ́lẹ̀ àríwá ìmọ́lẹ̀ ìmọ́lẹ̀ àpáta ìlà oòrùn.

sentence1: Canal Motorboats BV has two locations in the city
sentence1_translated: Canal Motorboats BV ní ibi méjì ní ìlú

sentence1: These open-air markets are also the most interesting places to shop in Beijing.
sentence1_translated: Àwọn ọjà yìí tún jẹ́ ibi tó dára jù lọ láti lọ rajà ní ìlú Beijing.

sentence1: Linked to Nova Scotia by the narrow Chignecto Isthmus, New Brunswick became a separate province in 1784 at the demand of 14,000 Loyalist refugees.
sentence1_translated: Ní ọdún 1784, New Brunswick di ìpínlẹ̀ tó yàtọ̀ sí ti Nova Scotia nítorí pé àwọn ọmọ abẹ́lẹ́yìn tó jẹ́ adúróṣinṣin tó wà ní ìpínlẹ̀ náà fẹ́ láti gba àtìsádi lọ sí orílẹ̀-èdè náà.

sentence1: The largest bay on the northwest coast makes a fine harbor, but both the water and the beach can be dirty.
sentence1_translated: Òkun tó tóbi jù lọ ní àríwá ìwọ̀ oòrùn ìlú yìí jẹ́ ibùdó tó dára, àmọ́ omi àti etíkun náà lè di ẹlẹ́gbin.

sentence1: Those skyscrapers are banks, and the street on which they stand has been nicknamed the Milla de Oro, or Golden Mile.
sentence1_translated: Àwọn ilé gogoro yẹn jẹ́ ojú ọ̀nà, wọ́n sì ń pe òpópónà tí wọ́n wà ní Milla de Oro, tàbí Golden Mile.

sentence1: Children will enjoy the Cite de la Mer (37 Rue de l'Asile Thomas), with exhibits on the history of boatbuilding, the fishing industry, and how tides and currents shape the coastline.
sentence1_translated: Àwọn ọmọdé yóò gbádùn ìlú Cite de la Mer (37 Rue de l'Asile Thomas), níbi tí wọ́n ti máa ń rí àwọn àfihàn nípa ìtàn iṣẹ́ títú ọkọ̀ ojú omi, iṣẹ́ ẹja àti bí òkun àti omi ṣe ń ṣàn tó.

sentence1: Natural enough, then, that involvement in World War II began with a British Commonwealth Air Training Plan, using Canada's safer skies to prepare pilots for combat.
sentence1_translated: Nítorí náà, ó ṣe kedere pé ètò kan tí ìjọba orílẹ̀-èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì ṣe láti dá àwọn awakọ̀ òfuurufú sílẹ̀ lọ́dún Ogun Àgbáyé Kejì yìí bẹ̀rẹ̀, èyí tó fi hàn pé àwọn awakọ̀ òfuurufú tó wà ní ààbò tó wà ní orílẹ̀-èdè Kánádà ti ń múra àwọn awakọ̀ òfuurufú sílẹ̀ fún ogun.

sentence1: The Ming Tombs were once a staple of tours to the Great Wall at Badaling, but foreign tourists have seldom been impressed by the site, finding it dank and poorly restored.
sentence1_translated: Àwọn Ibojì Ming jẹ́ ohun pàtàkì kan tí wọ́n máa ń ṣe nígbà tí wọ́n bá ń rìnrìn àjò lọ sí Òkè Ńlá Òkè ìlú Badaling, àmọ́ àwọn tó ń wá abúlé ilẹ̀ òkèèrè kì í sábà rí ohun tó ń ṣẹlẹ̀ níbẹ̀, torí pé wọ́n rí i pé ó ti ń ṣọ̀mù, kò sì tíì ṣàtúnṣe dáadáa.

sentence1: The best ports in the Mediterranean are June, July, August, and Mae,  said the 16th-century Venetian admiral Andrea Doria, noting that beyond the summer sailing season, a fleet couldn't do better than shelter here.
sentence1_translated: Àwọn èbúté tó dára jù lọ ní Mẹditaréníà ni June, July, August, àti Mae, gẹ́gẹ́ bí amíyalẹ́ Venetian Andrea Doria tó gbé ayé ní ọ̀rúndún kẹrìndínlógún ṣe sọ, ó sì sọ pé lẹ́yìn ìgbà tí wọ́n ń rìnrìn àjò nígbà ẹ̀ẹ̀rùn, kò sí òkun tó lè ṣe àwọn ọkọ̀ òkun tó dára ju pé kí wọ́n máa gbé níbí.

sentence1: Among the 27 hiking trails the best are the Glasgow Lakes trail to John Deer Lake and the trail around Beulach Ban Falls and French Mountain.
sentence1_translated: Lára àwọn ọ̀nà ìrìn àjò tó dára jù lọ tó wà láàárín àwọn ọ̀nà yìí ni ọ̀nà tó ń lọ sí àwọn adágún Glasgow tó ń lọ sí adágún John Deer àti ọ̀nà tó ń lọ síbi àwọn àkúnya omi Beulach Ban àti French Mountain.

sentence1: And they remain tolerant and helpful, even though they know that their lovely coast is no longer just theirs.
sentence1_translated: Wọ́n sì ń fara da ìṣòro wọn, wọ́n sì ń ràn wọ́n lọ́wọ́, bó tilẹ̀ jẹ́ pé wọ́n mọ̀ pé kì í ṣe àwọn nìkan ló ń gbé ní etíkun tó dára.

sentence1: Kublai Khan erected his own capital in 1279 on the shores of Beijing's Beihai Lake, where some of his imperial treasures remain on display today.
sentence1_translated: Kublai Khan gbé ìlú ńlá rẹ̀ kalẹ̀ ní ọdún 1279 ní etíkun adágún Beihai ní ìlú Beijing, níbi tí àwọn ìṣúra ọba rẹ̀ kan ṣì wà títí dòní.

sentence1: The roadless Na Pali Coast on the heavenly north shore is one of the world's most challenging and majestic seaside hikes (see page 71).
sentence1_translated: Òkun Na Pali tó wà ní etíkun àríwá ọ̀run, tó jẹ́ èyí tí kò sí ọ̀nà, jẹ́ ọ̀kan lára àwọn àgbègbè tó ṣòro jù lọ tí wọ́n ti ń rìnrìn àjò lọ sí etíkun tó sì tóbi jù lọ láyé (wo ojú ìwé 71).

sentence1: Assimilating more easily with the Anglo community only Protestant schools accepted their children Eastern European Jews have  graduated  to wealthy Westmount or emigrated, again, to Toronto.
sentence1_translated: Àwọn ilé ẹ̀kọ́ Pùròtẹ́sítáǹtì nìkan ló ń gba àwọn ọmọ wọn, àwọn Júù tó wà ní Ìlà Oòrùn Yúróòpù ló sì ti kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ yege ní Westmount tó jẹ́ ọlọ́rọ̀ tàbí tí wọ́n ti ṣí lọ sí Toronto.

sentence1: If possible, familiarize yourself with the plot in advance.
sentence1_translated: Tó bá ṣeé ṣe, kó o ti kọ́kọ́ mọ ohun tó ń ṣẹlẹ̀.

sentence1: His burial vaults, 27 m (88 ft) below ground, are made of marble and cover 1,200 sq m (13,000 sq ft).
sentence1_translated: Àwọn ààfin ìsìnkú rẹ̀ tó wà ní nǹkan bí mítà mẹ́tàdínlọ́gbọ̀n sí ààfin, wọ́n ṣe é láti inú márùmarè, ó sì tó mítà tó tó ẹgbẹ̀rún méjìlá [13,000] mítà.

sentence1: Napoleon attacked and destroyed Catalonia's sacred shrine, the monastery at Montserrat.
sentence1_translated: Napoleon gbéjà ko ibùdó mímọ́ tó wà nílùú Catalonia, ìyẹn ilé ẹ̀sìn Montserrat, ó sì pa á run.

sentence1: Remember to hide all portable possessions from the monkeys.
sentence1_translated: Rántí láti fi gbogbo ohun ìní tó o lè gbé pa mọ́ fún àwọn apè.

sentence1: Some 1,400 years before the Palace of Estei was erected, Milreu was also the large country house of an eminent person.
sentence1_translated: Ní nǹkan bí ẹgbẹ̀rún mẹ́rin [1,400] ọdún ṣáájú kí wọ́n tó gbé Ààfin Estei, ilé ńlá kan tó wà nílùú Milreu ni ọ̀kan lára àwọn tó gbajúmọ̀ jù lọ nínú àwọn èèyàn.

sentence1: With its entry into the Common Market in 1981, Greece's economic prospects strengthened.
sentence1_translated: Nígbà tí orílẹ̀-èdè Gíríìsì wọjà kan ní ọdún 1981, àwọn àbájáde ìṣúnná owó rẹ̀ túbọ̀ lágbára sí i.

sentence1: Sea temperatures vary between 18e and 24e C (64-75e F).
sentence1_translated: Àwọn ọ̀nà tí òkun gbà ń gbóná ni láti 18é sí 24é C (64-75é F).

sentence1: The Kinabalu national park is just one of six protected regions in the state.
sentence1_translated: Ọ̀kan lára àwọn àgbègbè mẹ́fà tí ìjọba ti dáàbò bò ni ọgbà àgbègbè Kinabalu.

sentence1: Sofias, next to the Megaro Mousikis Metro station.
sentence1_translated: Sofias, lẹ́gbẹ̀ẹ́ ibùdó mẹ́tèrọ̀ Megaro Mousikis.

sentence1: To the east of the gate is the Olympieion, site of the largest temple ever built on Greek soil.
sentence1_translated: Ìlà oòrùn ẹnu ọ̀nà náà ni Olympieion, ìyẹn ibi tí wọ́n ti kọ́ tẹ́ńpìlì tó tóbi jù lọ láyé àtijọ́ lórí ilẹ̀ Gíríìsì.

sentence1: The Poble Espanyol (Spanish Village), on Montjuac's northeastern flank, is an attraction for which the cliche  fun for the whole family  might have been invented.
sentence1_translated: Poble Espanyol (Ilé Èspanìkì), tó wà ní àríwá ìlà oòrùn ìlú Montjuac, jẹ́ ibi tí wọ́n ti ń ṣe eré ìnàjú fún gbogbo ìdílé.

sentence1: Today the old building hosts the Edinburgh Experience, a 20-minute, 3-D slide show charting the history of the city and bringing to life the Edinburgh of today (April-October only).
sentence1_translated: Lónìí, ilé náà ti di ibi tí wọ́n ti ń ṣe Àpéjọ Edinburgh Experience, ìyẹn àwòkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ àwòrán oníhòòhò oníwọ̀n mẹ́ẹ̀ẹ́dọ́gbọ̀n tó ń gbé ìtàn ìlú náà yẹ̀ wò, tó sì ń mú kí ìlú Edinburgh tó wà lóde òní (ìyẹn oṣù April sí October nìkan) wà láàyè.

sentence1: Dora Stratou Folk Dance Theater presents performances of traditional Greek song, dance, and music at a traditional  folk-village -type auditorium on Philopappos Hill from May to September daily except Mondays.
sentence1_translated: Dora Stratou Folk Dance Theatre ṣe awọn iṣẹ ti orin aṣa Greek, ijó, ati orin ni ile-iṣere ti aṣa ti ilu-ilu ti o wa lori Philoopappos Hill lati Oṣu Karun si Oṣu Kẹsan ojoojumọ ayafi awọn ọjọ Mọnde.

sentence1: You'll see videos of Anne's story and of Amsterdam under occupation along with photographs and artifacts of the time.
sentence1_translated: O máa rí fídíò ìtàn Anne àti ti ìlú Amsterdam tí wọ́n ń gbé lábẹ́ àkóso, títí kan àwọn fọ́tò àti àwọn nǹkan ìṣẹ̀ǹbáyé ìgbà yẹn.

sentence1: Beside it, the Norman Gothic La Martorana church, partly remodeled with a Baroque faaade and porch, has a fine campanile with four storys of slender mullioned windows.
sentence1_translated: Yàtọ̀ sí i, ṣọ́ọ̀ṣì La Martorana tí wọ́n ń pè ní Norman Gothic, tí wọ́n tún ṣe ní apá kan pẹ̀lú ilé ìjókòó àti ilé ìjókòó Baroque, ní ilé ìjókòó aláwọ̀ tó ní oríṣiríṣi òrùlé tó ní àwọn ojú fèrèsé tó ní àwọn òrùlé tó ń mú ọ̀nà jáde.

sentence1: The lake itself lies in the shadow of several high mountains, including Scafell Pike, the highest in England at 977 m (3,205 ft).
sentence1_translated: Òdìkejì òkun náà wà ní òjìji àwọn òkè ńlá tó ga, títí kan Scafell Pike, tó ga jù lọ ní England ní 977 m (3,205 ft).

sentence1: This collection of European and Puerto Rican art, probably the finest in the Caribbean, would be very much at home in any European capital.
sentence1_translated: Àwọn nǹkan tó wà nílẹ̀ Yúróòpù àti Puerto Rico yìí, tó ṣeé ṣe kó jẹ́ pé àwọn tó dára jù lọ nílẹ̀ Caribbean ni wọ́n máa ń kó jọ sí ìlú ńlá èyíkéyìí nílẹ̀ Yúróòpù.

sentence1: Treasure Beach is the only resort area to speak of, with just a handful of hotels stretching across three sandy bays.
sentence1_translated: Òkun Ìpínrọ̀ ni ibì kan ṣoṣo tó wà ní àgbègbè ìtura tó yẹ ká sọ̀rọ̀ nípa rẹ̀, àwọn ótẹ́lì díẹ̀ ló sì wà níbẹ̀ tó ń gba àgbègbè iyanrìn mẹ́ta kọjá.

sentence1: Then comes Bona, a center of basketry which also bills itself as the home of the kecak dance.
sentence1_translated: Lẹ́yìn náà ni Bona wá, ibùdó tí wọ́n ti ń ṣe ẹrù ìgò tí wọ́n sì ń ṣe é pẹ̀lú gẹ́gẹ́ bí ilé ìjó kécak.

sentence1: If you're feeling up to it, push on along the Mist Trail, past Emerald Pool, to Nevada Fall, and you'll begin to lose the crowds.
sentence1_translated: Tó o bá fẹ́ ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀, tẹ̀ lé Ọ̀nà Àdàrú, kọjá Emerald Pool, lọ sí Nevada Fall, wàá sì bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí í pàdánù àwọn èèyàn.

sentence1: Summer brings warm (but not hot) weather and warm sea temperatures, making it ideal for diving, snorkeling, and other water sports.
sentence1_translated: Nígbà ẹ̀ẹ̀rùn, ojú ọjọ́ máa ń gbóná (ṣugbọn kì í ṣe gbóná) àti òkun máa ń gbóná gan-an, èyí sì mú kó dára gan-an fún ṣíṣe ìgbọ́kọ̀, ṣíṣe ìgbọ́kọ̀ àti ṣíṣe eré ìmárale omi mìíràn.

sentence1: Among the ponds is one inhabited by  Visitors toss in coins in the hope of bouncing one off a turtle's head, a sure way of achieving good fortune.
sentence1_translated: Lára àwọn adágún omi náà ni ọ̀kan tí àwọn àlejò máa ń kó jọ, wọ́n sì máa ń fi owó ẹyọ kan ṣọ̀kọ̀ọ́, kí wọ́n lè rí owó náà yọ kúrò lára orí ẹyẹ kan, èyí sì jẹ́ ọ̀nà tó dájú láti rí ìbùkún gbà.

sentence1: Among the many jazz clubs are the famed Jazz Bakery in Culver City, the Catalina Bar and Grill in Hollywood, and the Baked Potato in North Hollywood.
sentence1_translated: Lára àwọn àgọ́ orin jazz tó gbajúmọ̀ jù lọ ni Jazz Bakery ní Culver City, Catalina Bar and Grill ní Hollywood, àti Baked Potato ní North Hollywood.

sentence1: At the center of the resort, in the sheltered waters of the inner lagoon, there is a  Swim with the Dolphins  program.
sentence1_translated: Ní àárín gbùngbùn ibi tí wọ́n ti ń ṣe ìtura náà, ní àwọn omi tó wà nínú aginjù inú, ètò àgbègbè Swim With Dolphins wà.

sentence1: The port town of Nafplio makes the perfect base for touring the area, or perhaps a spot to have lunch while on your tour.
sentence1_translated: Ìlú Nafplio tó wà ní èbúté yìí jẹ́ ibi tó dára jù lọ téèyàn lè gbà rìnrìn àjò lọ sí àgbègbè náà, tàbí kó jẹ́ ibi tó dára jù lọ téèyàn lè jẹun déédéé nígbà tó bá wà ní ìrìn àjò náà.

sentence1: Some of its residents are descendants of the valiant laborers who helped build the Canadian Pacific Railway.
sentence1_translated: Àwọn kan lára àwọn tó ń gbé níbẹ̀ jẹ́ àtọmọdọ́mọ àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ onígboyà tó ṣèrànwọ́ láti kọ́ ọkọ̀ ojú irin kan tó ń jẹ́ Canadian Pacific Railway.

sentence1: Get off at the stop before Batthyany ter to admire the colourful exterior of the 1896 Neo-Gothic Calvinist Church which features in so many panoramas of the city.
sentence1_translated: Wá ibùdó tó wà níwájú Batthyany ter láti wo inú ilé ìsìn Calvinist Neo-Gothic ti ọdún 1896 tó ní ọ̀pọ̀ ojú ọ̀nà tó gbà wo ìlú náà.

sentence1: It was here in 1775 that 100 barrels of gunpowder mysteriously disappeared from stores in Fort St. Catherine and found their way onto a boat bound for the use of the American revolutionaries.
sentence1_translated: Ní ọdún 1775, àwọn bàrálì bàrá ọgọ́rùn-ún ló pa run nínú ilé ìtajà tó wà ní Fort St. Catherine, wọ́n sì wọ ọkọ̀ ojú omi kan tí àwọn ológun ilẹ̀ Amẹ́ríkà fẹ́ lò.

sentence1: Others well worth visiting include the home of Balzac (47 Rue Rayanouard) and Delacroix's studio (6 Rue de Furstenberg).
sentence1_translated: Àwọn ilé míì tó yẹ ká lọ máa rí ni ilé Balzac (47 Rue Rayanouard) àti ilé iṣẹ́ Delacroix (6 Rue de Furstenberg).

sentence1: In Prinsengracht, Otto Frank and his family hid in the attic of their business premises for over two years before being discovered.
sentence1_translated: Nílùú Prinsengracht, Otto Frank àti ìdílé rẹ̀ fi ohun tó lé ní ọdún méjì fara pa mọ́ sínú òrùlé ilé iṣẹ́ wọn kí wọ́n tó rí i.

sentence1: If you've become an adept of the tea ceremony, you'll appreciate the excellent collection of 14th-century  ceramic tea bowls, tea kettles, and caddies, as well as bamboo spoons, whisks, and flower vases.
sentence1_translated: Tó o bá ti mọṣẹ́ dáadáa nínú ayẹyẹ tá à ń ṣe fún àtí, wàá mọrírì àwọn àpò ọ̀ṣọ́ àgbá, àwọn ìkòkò àti àwọn àpò tí wọ́n fi ṣe àtítí tí wọ́n wà ní ọ̀rúndún kẹrìnlá, àtàwọn bàbà tí wọ́n fi ṣe àtíbà, àwọn àpò àti àwọn àpò òdòdó.

sentence1: The showpieces are the new lion exhibit, snow leopard and cheetah exhibits, and an African tropical rain forest, which is complete with gorillas and warthogs.
sentence1_translated: Àwọn ohun tó wà níbẹ̀ ni ìfihàn kìnnìún tuntun, ìfihàn kìnnìún àti ẹyẹ ìkálẹ̀, àti igbó òjò tó ń ṣàn nílẹ̀ Áfíríkà, tó kún fún àwọn gorila àti àwọn ìkálẹ̀.

sentence1: Even the location of the building is a technological marvel.
sentence1_translated: Kódà, ibi tí ilé náà wà jẹ́ iṣẹ́ ìyanu nípa ìmọ̀ ẹ̀rọ.

sentence1: In fact, it was the flashpoint for protests and riots during the busing controversy in the 1970s.
sentence1_translated: Kódà, ó jẹ́ ibi tí àwọn èèyàn ti ń ṣàròyé àti ìjàngbọ̀n wáyé nígbà tí wọ́n ń ṣe ìjàngbọ̀n lórí ọkọ̀ òfuurufú ní ọdún 1970.

sentence1: Famous for its August log-rolling contests, the town of Squamish makes a useful base for hiking tours into Garibaldi Provincial Park.
sentence1_translated: Ìlú Squamish tó gbajúmọ̀ fún ìdíje tí wọ́n ń ṣe láti fi gbé igi jáde ní oṣù August jẹ́ ibi tó wúlò fún ìrìn àjò ìta gbangba sí Pápá Ìpín Ìpínlẹ̀ Garibaldi.

sentence1: For an authentic feel of old Portugal, slip into the cool entrance hall of theimpressive Leal Senado ( Loyal Senate  building), a fine example of colonial architecture.
sentence1_translated: Láti lè rí ojúlówó ìrírí ilẹ̀ Pùtígálì ìgbàanì, wọ inú yàrá ìbalẹ̀ tó tutù ti ilé Leal Senado tó wúni lórí, èyí tó jẹ́ àpẹẹrẹ àtàtà nípa ilé ìṣàkóso àwọn aráàlú.

sentence1: (The event is repeated on 14-15 August. )
sentence1_translated: (A tún àpéjọ náà ṣe ní ọjọ́ kẹrìnlá sí ìkẹ́wàá oṣù kẹjọ.)

sentence1: Dominating the mouth of Sant Antoni Bay is the gaunt silhouette of the island of Coniera, or Conejera (meaning  rabbit's warren  or  burrow ).
sentence1_translated: Àwòrán tó ń ṣàkóso ẹnu òkun Sant Antoni Bay ni àwòrán tó ń mú kí òkun tó ń múni lọ sókè tó ń múni lọ sókè tó ń múni lọ sókè tó ń múni lọ sókè tó ń múni lọ sókè tó ń múni lọ sókè tó ń múni lọ sókè tó ń múni lọ sókè tó ń múni lọ sókè tó ń múni lọ sókè tó ń múni lọ sókè tó ń múni lọ sókè tó ń múni lọ sókè tó ń múni lọ sókè tó ń múni lọ sókè tó ń múni lọ sókè tó ń múni lọ sókè tó ń múni lọ sókè tó ń múni lọ sókè tó sì ń múni lọ sókè tó ń múni lọ sókè tó ń múni lọ sókè tó sì ń múni lọ sókè tó ń gbé).

sentence1: These link the main public beaches (from Warwick Long Bay to Horseshoe Bay).
sentence1_translated: Àwọn ojúewé wọ̀nyí ń so àwọn etíkun tó wà ní àgbègbè ìlú náà pọ̀ (láti Warwick Long Bay sí Horseshoe Bay).

sentence1: During the Sixth Crusade (1228- 1229), the Holy Roman Emperor Frederick II managed to secure Jerusalem for the Christians by negotiation.
sentence1_translated: Nígbà Ogun Àjíǹde Kẹfà (1228 sí 1229), Ọba Róòmù Mímọ́ Frederick II ṣe ìfọ̀rọ̀wérọ̀ láti dáàbò bo Jerúsálẹ́mù fún àwọn Kristẹni.

sentence1: Forming part of the city wall, the gate was intended by the more pragmatic Prussians not so much as a triumphal arch as an imposing tollgate for collecting duties.
sentence1_translated: Àwọn ará Prussia tó jẹ́ oníwà rere jù lọ ló ṣe àbáwọlé náà, kì í ṣe àbáwọlé ìṣẹ́gun tó jẹ́ ọ̀nà ìbílẹ̀ tó dára jù lọ, bí kò ṣe àbáwọlé tí wọ́n ń gbà láti gba owó orí.

sentence1: Apart from the set pieces, most of the music is percussive and serves to support and reflect the action and mood.
sentence1_translated: Yàtọ̀ sí àwọn orin tó wà nínú ìjókòó, èyí tó pọ̀ jù lọ lára àwọn orin náà ni orin tó ń gbéni ró, èyí sì ń jẹ́ kí ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ àti ìmí ẹ̀dùn náà túbọ̀ máa ń gbòòrò sí i.

sentence1: The pattern repeated itself a century later when the Moors invoked the aid of the Almohads in 1151.
sentence1_translated: Ọdún kan lẹ́yìn náà, àwọn ará Moor tún ń ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀ nígbà tí wọ́n wá ìrànlọ́wọ́ àwọn Almohad lọ́dún 1151.

sentence1: You can buy several of these to make your own line of narrow gables.
sentence1_translated: O lè ra ọ̀pọ̀ lára wọn kó o lè ṣe àwọn ọ̀pá ìsọfúnni tó o ní.

sentence1: From May to mid-October, the Boston Harbor Cruise Company (Tel.
sentence1_translated: Láti oṣù May sí ìdajì oṣù October, ilé iṣẹ́ Boston Harbor Cruise Company (Tel.

sentence1: The sea is reached only by narrow lanes and farm tracks, but it's worth a trek to get away from the crowds.
sentence1_translated: Òkun náà jẹ́ ọ̀nà tóóró àti ọ̀nà tó lọ sọ́dọ̀ àwọn àgbẹ̀, àmọ́ ó yẹ kéèyàn rìnrìn àjò kan kó lè sá kúrò lọ́dọ̀ àwọn èèyàn.

sentence1: With reinforcements, the Spaniards managed to establish a beachhead.
sentence1_translated: Àwọn ará Sípéènì fi àwọn ìtìlẹ́yìn wọn kọ́kọ́ gbẹ́tẹ́lẹ̀ kan tó ń gbé etíkun.

sentence1: Even so, Paris recently created miles of cycling lanes that crisscross the entire city, making bicycling much safer (and more popular).
sentence1_translated: Síbẹ̀, ní báyìí, ìlú Paris ti dá ọ̀nà tó jìnnà réré tó máa ń gba ìlú náà kọjá, èyí sì mú kí ìrìn àjò kẹ̀kẹ́ túbọ̀ rọrùn (tó sì gbajúmọ̀) sí i.

sentence1: You will find a pleasant beach nearby at Batu Hitam.
sentence1_translated: O lè rí etíkun tó dára nítòsí ní Batu Hitam.

sentence1: In horse-drawn carts you visit costumed villagers tilling and harvesting, sheep-shearing, grinding flour in the mill, weaving, and fashioning horseshoes in the smithy.
sentence1_translated: Nínú kẹ̀kẹ́ ẹṣin tó ń fa ẹṣin, o máa ń lọ sọ́dọ̀ àwọn ará abúlé tó ní aṣọ tó ń ṣiṣẹ́ àgbẹ̀, tó ń kórè, tó ń gé àgùntàn, tó ń fi ìyẹ̀fun pòròpórò ṣe àgbẹ̀, tó ń ṣe ọ̀rọ̀ ọ̀rọ̀ àti tó ń ṣe àpáta ẹṣin ní ilé iṣẹ́ àfọwọ́n.

sentence1: Smaller boats for local jaunts can be rented at Sea Horse Boat Rentals, Marsh Harbour, Abacos (Tel.
sentence1_translated: Àwọn ọkọ̀ ojú omi tó kéré jù lọ fún àwọn tó ń rìnrìn àjò ládùúgbò lè wà ní ilé ìtajà ọkọ̀ ojú omi Sea Horse Boat Rentals, Marsh Harbour, Abacos (Tel.

sentence1: The outrageous and conservative, one learns, coexist here without much fuss.
sentence1_translated: Àwọn tó ń ṣe ohun tó burú jáì àtàwọn tó ń ṣe ohun tó ń mú kí nǹkan rí bí nǹkan ṣe rí lára wọn máa ń gbé pọ̀ níbí láìní ìdààmú kankan.

sentence1: The cross is said to weigh 181,740 tons.
sentence1_translated: Wọ́n sọ pé àwọ̀n àgbélébùú náà tó ẹgbẹ̀rún méjìdínlọ́gọ́rin àti méje ó lé ẹgbàá [181,740] tọn.

sentence1: The ruthless defense minister Gustav Noske called in 4,000 Freikorps (right-wing storm-troopers) to smash the movement.
sentence1_translated: Olùṣọ́ Ààbò Gustav Noske, tó jẹ́ aláàánú, pe ẹgbẹ̀rún mẹ́rin [4,000] lára àwọn ọmọ ogun Freikorps (àwọn ọmọ ogun jàǹdùkú ológun) láti pa àwọn ọmọ ogun náà run.

sentence1: Today, tour groups come for short stays and, as everywhere in Bali, standards and prices are steadily going up.
sentence1_translated: Lónìí, àwọn àwùjọ tó ń rìnrìn àjò máa ń wá ṣe ìtìjú fún àkókò kúkúrú, bí wọ́n ti ń ṣe ní gbogbo àgbègbè Bali, àwọn ìlànà àti iye owó tí wọ́n ń ná ń pọ̀ sí i.

sentence1: It was they who made the first and hardiest effort to hew a modern living out of this hard land.
sentence1_translated: Àwọn ni wọ́n kọ́kọ́ ṣe gbogbo ohun tí wọ́n lè ṣe láti mú kí ayé tó le yìí ṣeé gbé.

sentence1: Built in a.d. 688-691, it is decorated in thousands of exquisite, predominantly blue and yellow, Persian ceramic tiles, with Koranic scriptures on the lintels.
sentence1_translated: Wọ́n kọ́ ọ́ lọ́dún 688 sí 691 Sànmánì Kristẹni, wọ́n fi ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún ọ̀rọ̀ aláwọ̀ búlúù àti aláwọ̀ pupa tí wọ́n fi ṣe ọ̀ṣọ́, wọ́n fi ọ̀rọ̀ Kóránì ṣe ọ̀ṣọ́.

sentence1: Notice how the trompe l'oeil painting on the low arched ceiling aspires to turn the little church into a lofty Gothic cathedral.
sentence1_translated: Kíyè sí bí àwòrán trompe l'oeil tó wà lórí òrùlé tó ní àwọ̀n tó wà nísàlẹ̀ ṣe fẹ́ sọ ṣọ́ọ̀ṣì kékeré yìí di ilé ìsìn Gothic tó ga.

sentence1: Some Athenians even urged the Assembly to declare war on the Macedonian King.
sentence1_translated: Àwọn ará Áténì kan tiẹ̀ rọ Ìgbìmọ̀ náà pé kí wọ́n kéde ogun sí Ọba Makedóníà.

sentence1: Freshwater anglers must have a permit ask at the nearest tourist office for information on how to obtain one.
sentence1_translated: Àwọn tó ń pẹja ní òkun ọ̀gbìn ní láti ní ìwé àṣẹ láti béèrè fún ìsọfúnni nípa bí wọ́n ṣe lè rí ìwé àṣẹ náà gbà ní ilé iṣẹ́ tó sún mọ́ àwọn tó ń ṣeré ìrìn-àjò.

sentence1: To see some of Cluny's impact on the surrounding countryside, visit a few of the villages whose Romanesque churches were built by Cluny's architects and  among them, Saint-Vincent-des-Pres, Taize, Berze-la-Ville, and Malay.
sentence1_translated: Láti rí ipa tí Cluny ní lórí àwọn àgbègbè tó yí i ká, lọ sí àwọn abúlé mélòó kan tí àwọn ọ̀mọ̀wé Cluny kọ́ àwọn ṣọ́ọ̀ṣì Romanesque wọn, títí kan Saint-Vincent-des-Pres, Taize, Berze-la-Ville àti Malay.

sentence1: Only hikes accompanied by guides from the local guiding cooperative are advised.
sentence1_translated: Àwọn ìrìn àjò tó bá wà ní ìfẹ̀gbẹ́kẹ̀gbẹ́ tó ń darí àwọn èèyàn ládùúgbò nìkan ni a máa ń gbà níyànjú láti ṣe.

sentence1: At the moment, the thinking is that it's perhaps best to leave these smaller, less developed islands in peace.
sentence1_translated: Ní báyìí, èrò wa ni pé ó dára gan-an ká fi àwọn erékùṣù kékeré tí kò tíì dàgbà yìí sílẹ̀ ní àlàáfíà.

sentence1: One inmate returning for the guided tour surprisingly, some do, out of nostalgia said the food was better than he had eaten in many San Francisco hotels.
sentence1_translated: Ọ̀kan lára àwọn ẹlẹ́wọ̀n tó ń padà bọ̀ fún ìbẹ̀wò tó ń ṣamọ̀nà, ó yà á lẹ́nu pé, àwọn kan gbà, nítorí pé wọ́n ń ṣàníyàn nípa oúnjẹ náà, wọ́n sọ pé oúnjẹ náà sàn ju èyí tó jẹ nínú ọ̀pọ̀ òtẹ́ẹ̀lì tó wà nílùú San Francisco lọ.

sentence1: Even in these early times the gods would be consulted with the oracle issuing their verdicts from the Rock of Sybil.
sentence1_translated: Kódà ní àwọn ìgbà yẹn, àwọn ọlọ́run máa ń gba ìtọ́ni látọ̀dọ̀ ọ̀rọ̀ ẹnu ọ̀nà tí wọ́n ń sọ pé wọ́n máa dájọ́ lórí àwọn ohun tó ń ṣẹlẹ̀ ní Àpáta Ńlá Síbílì.

sentence1: The Baixada de Santa Eulalia descends to carrer dels Banys Nous, named for the long-gone  new  baths of the ghetto erected in the 12th century.
sentence1_translated: Baixada de Santa Eulalia ń lọ sí carrer dels Banys Nous, tí orúkọ rẹ̀ wá látinú àwọn ilé ìwẹ̀ tuntun tí wọ́n ti gbé kalẹ̀ ní ọ̀rúndún kẹtàlá.

sentence1: Once you're off the traffic-squeezed main arteries, you'll find that Albufeira's old town preserves a surprising bit of traditional charm.
sentence1_translated: Tó o bá ti kúrò ní àwọn òpópónà tó kún fún ọkọ̀, wàá rí i pé ìlú ńlá Albufeira ní ohun tó ń múni láyọ̀ gan-an.

sentence1: Close to the original action and still providing the most vivid testimony to the Klondike days, the boomtown of Dawson City yielded in 1951 to the transportation and communications center of Whitehorse as territorial capital.
sentence1_translated: Ní àárín ìgbésẹ̀ tó wáyé ní ìpilẹ̀ṣẹ̀, tó sì ṣì ń jẹ́rìí sí àwọn àkókò tó wà ní Klondike, ìlú Dawson City tó ń gbé ní ìlọsíwájú ti fi ìlú Whitehorse tó jẹ́ olú ìlú àgbègbè fún àwọn èèyàn ní ọdún 1951.

sentence1: This was the island bought by Errol Flynn when he settled in Port Antonio in 1946
sentence1_translated: Errol Flynn ló ra erékùṣù yìí nígbà tó kọ́kọ́ gbé ní Port Antonio lọ́dún 1946.

sentence1: Cala Mondrage is practically undeveloped (by the standards of coastal Mallorca), and may stay that way by order of the regional government, which has become alarmed by the specter of unchecked building along the coast.
sentence1_translated: Cala Mondrage kò tíì di ìlú tó wà ní àgbègbè náà lágbègbè náà (ní ìbámu pẹ̀lú ìlànà tó wà ní etíkun Mallorca), ó sì lè wà nírú ipò náà lábẹ́ àṣẹ ìjọba àgbègbè tó ti ń sọni di òǹrorò nítorí pé àwọn ilé tí kò sí lágbègbè náà ti ń wà ní àgbègbè náà kò ṣeé ṣe láti kọ́.

sentence1: It has three meru-topped shrines dedicated to Brahma, Shiva, and Vishnu.
sentence1_translated: Ó ní àwọn ibi ìjọsìn mẹ́ta tó ní oríṣiríṣi oríṣiríṣi tó yà sí Brahma, Shiva àti Vishnu.

sentence1: Less than a mile past the Arboretum, you will find two churches on the right side of the road, backed by hundreds of white painted family tombs on the hillside.
sentence1_translated: Kò tó nǹkan bí kìlómítà kan lẹ́yìn ilé ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ náà, wàá rí ṣọ́ọ̀ṣì méjì ní apá ọ̀tún ọ̀nà, tí ọgọ́rọ̀ọ̀rún òkúta ìdílé tí wọ́n yà sí àwọ̀ funfun ló wà ní ọ̀nà náà.

sentence1: The Stampede was originally conceived to show all the techniques and excitement of rounding up cattle on the prairies.
sentence1_translated: Wọ́n kọ́kọ́ dá Stampede yìí sílẹ̀ láti fi hàn pé ó ṣeé ṣe láti kó àwọn ẹran jọ sórí pápá.

sentence1: Almost 100,000 people a day come here to marvel at the striking architecture and explore the latest attractions in this ever-changing city.
sentence1_translated: Ó fẹ́rẹ̀ẹ́ tó ẹgbẹ̀rún kan èèyàn lójoojúmọ́ tó ń wá síbẹ̀ láti wá wo àwọn ohun tó ń múni láyọ̀ tó sì ń múni láyọ̀ nínú ìlú tó ń yí padà yìí.

sentence1: The Beaux Arts City Hall has been replaced by nearby Government Center.
sentence1_translated: Ilé Ìgbìmọ̀ Olùdarí Beaux Arts ti di àdúgbò kan tó wà nítòsí.

sentence1: Behind the hotel, beyond an 1898 statue of Samuel de Champlain, the city's founder, Dufferin Terrace offers a magnificent view over the St. Lawrence and downriver to the Ile d'Orleans.
sentence1_translated: Lẹ́yìn òtẹ́ẹ̀lì náà, lẹ́yìn ère Samuel de Champlain tó dá ìlú náà sílẹ̀ lọ́dún 1898, Dufferin Terrace ń fúnni ní ojú tó fani mọ́ra lórí odò St. Lawrence àti odò tó ń ṣàn sí Ile d'Orleans.

sentence1: Beyond Payangan, the little-used road wends its way through scenic countryside all the way to Batur (see pagea59).
sentence1_translated: Nípa títì Payangan, ọ̀nà tí kò fi bẹ́ẹ̀ lò dáadáa yìí ń gba àgbègbè tó ní ojú ọ̀nà tó dára kọjá lọ sí Batur (wo ojú ìwé 59).

sentence1: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), founded in 1861 is America's leading science and engineering establishment that has pioneered many modern technologies, from stroboscopic photography to food preservation processes.
sentence1_translated: Ilé Ẹ̀kọ́ Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), tí wọ́n dá sílẹ̀ lọ́dún 1861, ni ilé ẹ̀kọ́ àti ilé iṣẹ́ ẹ̀rọ tó ń gbéni ró ní Amẹ́ríkà, ó sì ti ṣe aṣáájú-ọ̀nà nínú ọ̀pọ̀ ìmọ̀ ẹ̀rọ òde òní, láti àwòrán tó ń gbéni lọ́nà ìràwọ̀ sí àwọn ọ̀nà tí wọ́n ń gbà tọ́jú oúnjẹ.

sentence1: Six kilometers (4 miles) north of Ipoh is the Perak Tong, built in 1926 by a Buddhist priest from China.
sentence1_translated: Ìlú Perak Tong tó wà ní àríwá ìlú Ipoh tó jìnnà sí ìlú náà tó nǹkan bí kìlómítà mẹ́fà ni wọ́n kọ́ lọ́dún 1926 lẹ́yìn tí àlùfáà kan tó jẹ́ ẹlẹ́sìn Búdà láti orílẹ̀-èdè Ṣáínà gbé e ró.

sentence1: Kodaly kerend (Kodaly crescent, named after another Hungarian composer) is a splendid ensemble, its curving faaades decorated with Classical  gures and inlaid motifs.
sentence1_translated: Kodaly kerend (ìyẹn ìlà oòrùn Kodaly, tí a pè ní orúkọ òǹkọ̀wé Hungary mìíràn) jẹ́ àwùjọ àgbàyanu kan, àwọn àgbá tó ní àyíká tó ní àwọn ohun èlò àwọ̀n àti àwọn ohun èlò tí wọ́n fi ọ̀nà àwọ̀n ṣe ọ̀ṣọ.

sentence1: Plans to house parliament here after Independence came to nothing
sentence1_translated: Àwọn àbá láti kó ilé ìgbìmọ̀ aṣòfin síbí lẹ́yìn tí Ìbò Àti-Òmìnira dé kò sí.

sentence1: Examples of every locally produced craft can be found in abundance here, and you'll shop cheaper than in the resorts, especially if you practice your bartering skills beforehand.
sentence1_translated: Àwọn àpẹẹrẹ àwọn iṣẹ́ ọwọ́ tó ń lọ lọ́wọ́ ládùúgbò ló pọ̀ gan-an níbí, wàá sì máa rajà ní ìnáwó tó dín kù ju àwọn ibi tí wọ́n ti ń ra oúnjẹ lọ, pàápàá tó o bá ti kọ́kọ́ kọ́ ọ lẹ́kọ̀ọ́ nípa bí wàá ṣe máa ṣe iṣẹ́ ajé.

sentence1: The 60-year rule of Ramses II (1279-1212 b.c. ) was a great finale to the New Kingdom era.
sentence1_translated: Ọdún mẹ́rìndínláàádọ́rin tí Rámésésì Kejì (1279 sí 1212 ṣáájú Sànmánì Kristẹni) fi ṣàkóso ni ìparí àkókò Ìjọba Tuntun.

sentence1: From the air you'll be able to see that Sarawak boasts the country's longest river, the Rejang, flowing 563 km (351 miles) from the mountains on the Indonesian border to the South China Sea.
sentence1_translated: Láti ojú òfuurufú ni wàá ti lè rí i pé odò tó gùn jù lọ ní orílẹ̀-èdè náà ni odò Rejang, tó ń ṣàn ní nǹkan bí àádọ́ta ó lé mẹ́ta [563 km] láti àwọn òkè tó wà ní ààlà ilẹ̀ Indonesia dé Òkun Gúúsù China.

sentence1: An entrance tunnel with a kitchen alcove on one side, and storage alcoves on the other, leads to the main living area.
sentence1_translated: Ọ̀nà àbáwọlé kan tó ní àbáwọlé ibi ìdáná ní apá kan, àti àbáwọlé ibi ìṣẹ̀ǹbáyé ní apá kejì, ló ń lọ sí ibi ìgbẹ́ pàtàkì.

sentence1: The National Theater and Concert Hall, Tel. 01-7282333, more commonly known as the Megaron, is situated on Vas.
sentence1_translated: Ile-iṣere ati Ile-iṣere ti Orilẹ-ede, Tel. 01-7282333, ti a mọ bi Megaron, wa ni Vas.

sentence1: Although it helps if you have an interest in American politics, the displays allowing you to listen to a Watergate tape or  interview  Nixon on foreign affairs are nevertheless interesting.
sentence1_translated: Bó tilẹ̀ jẹ́ pé ó máa ń ṣèrànwọ́ tó o bá fẹ́ mọ nípa ìṣèlú Amẹ́ríkà, síbẹ̀ àwọn ìsọfúnni tó ń jẹ́ kó o lè fetí sí fíìmù Watergate tàbí ìfọ̀rọ̀wérọ̀ pẹ̀lú Nixon lórí ọ̀ràn ọ̀ràn ọ̀ràn ilẹ̀ òkèèrè ṣì máa ń ṣe é láǹfààní.

sentence1: The town's other great Roman monument, the theatre antique, is on the south side of town.

sentence1: The building constructed above the underground quarters of the SS guards houses the Topographie des Terrors, an exhibition of photographs and documents which movingly illustrates the lives of those who resisted the Nazi terror.

sentence1: The island's tranquility lasted until 1287, when Alfonso III of Aragen, smarting over a series of humiliations at the hands of his nobles, found a pretext for invasion.

sentence1: On a platform above the columns is a carved figure of Chaac-Mool in reclining position, its belly hollowed into a bowl to receive offerings some experts think these included human hearts fresh from the body.
sentence1_translated: Ní orí pèpéle kan tó wà lókè àwọn òpó náà, wọ́n rí àwòrán Chaac-Mool tó wà ní ipò tó ti dùbúlẹ̀, tí wọ́n fi ìfun rẹ̀ ṣú sínú àwo kan láti gba ọrẹ ẹbọ. Àwọn ògbógi kan rò pé ọkàn èèyàn tó ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ jáde lára ara ni wọ́n fi wà lára àwọn ẹ̀dá yìí.

sentence1: They love to socialize, and bars particularly the famous  brown bars  are the place where they meet, usually to put the world to rights.

sentence1: The Liao capital at Beijing, then known as Yanjing, occupied the southeast region of what is the modern capital today, with the Fayuan Temple the only surviving monument.

sentence1: See the list of beach highlights on pages 82 and 85.

sentence1: You can walk the decks or even take a two-hour cruise on this replica of the famous 1921 champion sailship portrayed on the Canadian ten-cent coin.

sentence1: In past centuries, however, it was the haunt of Caribbean pirates, being far from the clutches of colonial overlords in Havana, San Juan in Puerto Rico, and Panama City, the nearest colonial outposts.

sentence1: Tourist offices have tried to rename the area L'Estrie, but even the most militant Quebecois prefer the customary direct, if approximate, translation of the  Cantons de l'Est.

sentence1: After two centuries of religious heresy, the Church needed a spiritual renewal, finding the perfect ally in Francis of Assisi (1182-1226), pious without being troublesomely militant.

sentence1: As it snakes up and down the peaks and ridges, the wall conforms to a challenging topography, one that leaves many tourists gasping for breath.

sentence1: But with all the new-fangled razzmatazz, the museum hasn't forgotten the charm of mint-condition antique cars and, above all, old train engines behemoths from the great era of steam that truly  made  Canada.

sentence1: Madrid's collection of Spanish Old Masters Vealazquez, El Greaco, Goya, Zurabaran, and more is unarivalled in the world.

sentence1: The Maritime Museum traces the history of the Pacific port.

sentence1: Kilometer 7 sees a right turn to the 18-hole Pok-Ta-Pok golf course, which is located on a large land-mass that juts out into the lagoon.

sentence1: Dam Square was landlocked for the first time in its history.
sentence1_translated: Ìgbà àkọ́kọ́ nínú ìtàn rẹ̀ ni Dam Square kò sí ojú òkun.

sentence1: Colenia de Sant Jordi is lined with hotels and villas, but it seems a rather half-hearted attempt at a resort.

sentence1: Such boats were developed to allow quick access to incoming ships.
sentence1_translated: Wọ́n ṣe irú ọkọ̀ ojú omi bẹ́ẹ̀ láti jẹ́ kí ọkọ̀ ojú omi tó ń bọ̀ lè tètè wọlé.

sentence1: In 1847, a savage uprising known as the Caste War saw Mayan rebels massacre white settlers and take control of nearly two-thirds of the peninsula.
sentence1_translated: Lọ́dún 1847, ìdìtẹ̀ kan tó burú jáì tí wọ́n ń pè ní Ogun Àwọn Àgbà ló mú kí àwọn ọmọ ogun Maya pa àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ Mayan tó jẹ́ aláwọ̀ funfun run, wọ́n sì gba nǹkan bí ìdá méjì nínú ìdá mẹ́ta ilẹ̀ tó wà lórí erékùṣù náà.

sentence1: Leaf monkeys and long-tailed macaques are among the wildlife.

sentence1: You'll find these in various sizes and with different decoration.
sentence1_translated: O lè rí wọn ní oríṣiríṣi àbùdá àti àwọn ohun èlò tó yàtọ̀ síra.

sentence1: Nearby Xlapak has only one major structure, a palace, but Labna, the final Puuc site on the tour, has a number of structures to explore.
sentence1_translated: Ilé kan ṣoṣo ṣoṣo tó wà nítòsí ìlú Xlapak ni ààfin, àmọ́ ìlú Labna, tó jẹ́ ibì kan tí àwọn ará Puuc ti ń rìnrìn àjò náà ti parí, ní àwọn ilé tó pọ̀ láti ṣèwádìí.

sentence1: The edifice links two identical churches, the Franzesischer Dom (or French Cathedral) to the north, built for the immigrant Huguenots, and the Deutscher Dom (German Cathedral) to the south.
sentence1_translated: Ilé náà so àwọn ṣọ́ọ̀ṣì méjì kan náà, Franzesischer Dom (tàbí Katidírálì Faranse) sí àríwá, tí a kó fún àwọn Huguenots tó wá láti orílẹ̀-èdè míì, àti Deutscher Dom (Katedírálì Jẹmánì) sí gúúsù.

sentence1: Visitors can also see a 28-minute  virtual history  multimedia film about Barcino-Barcelona.

sentence1: One is cautioned about eating food openly, as the monkeys are likely to view this as an invitation to dine.

sentence1: Amsterdam has many facets, almost as many as the diamonds for which the city is famous.

sentence1: Look out for coconut rum and other fruit rums there's a tremendous variety.

sentence1: This letter is to let you know that, while we've experienced some success this season, we still need your help to continue our record of strong fiscal management and vibrant theatrical productions.

sentence1: This letter is to let you know that we still need your help to continue our record of strong fiscal management, vibrant theatrical productions and outstanding educational programs.

sentence1: And yet within change there will be continuity.

sentence1: Without your help we will lose some of this grant money.

sentence1: Unlike other not-for-profit theatres in the city, our actors make their living from their craft.

sentence1: Some American place names have a unique resonance about them--places like Maggie's Nipples, Wyoming, or Greasy Creek, Arkansas, Lickskillet, Kentucky, or Scroungeout, Alabama.

sentence1: Despite their reputation for distrusting polyglots, it is by no means unusual for Englishmen to be bilingual.

sentence1: Thus, once a pleasing motif has been discovered, the next least exerting is to reproduce it with a slight variation.

sentence1: The Auld Alliance, a treaty of accord between France and Scotland, was born.

sentence1: This is not to say that the Western tradition has a monopoly on Niceness.

sentence1: The major Italian guidebook to Rome soberly claims that this building has been nicknamed Il Colosseo Quadrato , `The Square Colosseum.

sentence1: Via di Ripetta imperceptibly merges into Via della Scrofa `Street of the Sow,' named after another ancient sculpture that is still preserved there.

sentence1: And rest easy, Miss Dalrymple, when I reedit speech scripts for print publication, I always revert to good old academically pure English usage.
sentence1_translated: Ó sì tún máa ń rọrùn fún mi láti dá ara mi lóhùn, ọ̀gbẹ́ni Dalrymple, nígbà tí mo bá ń tún àwọn ìwé tí mo ń kọ ṣe, tí mo sì ń ṣe ìtẹ̀jáde, mo máa ń pa dà sí èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì tí kò ní ẹ̀kọ́ èké.

sentence1: There is a linguistic process in the evolution of our vocabulary that is not functioning with a high rate of efficiency.

sentence1: A number of them might have been created by prisoners whose vocabularies were too small to accommodate the concepts, events, or situations named.

sentence1: Inglish differs from English in five  words, expressions, grammar, pronunciation and rhythm.

sentence1: One must be very cautious in proposing etymologies that attribute the origin of a word to playfulness or  they often turn out to be folk etymologies and totally empty of anything more than hollow speculation.
sentence1_translated: Ó yẹ ká ṣọ́ra gan-an nígbà tá a bá ń sọ àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ tó ń sọ pé ọ̀rọ̀ kan wá látinú eré tàbí pé àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ náà sábà máa ń jẹ́ ọ̀rọ̀ tó ń sọni di èèyàn, tí kò sì ní ohunkóhun tó lè fi hàn pé òótọ́ lọ̀rọ̀ náà.

sentence1: Davidson should not adopt the pronunciation of scone to rhyme with `bone'--at any rate not because Victoria, where he lives, is  veddy English.
sentence1_translated: Davidson kò yẹ ki o gba awọn pronunciation ti scone lati rhyme pẹlu `bone' - ni eyikeyi idiyele ko nitori Victoria, ibi ti o ngbe, jẹ Veddy English.

sentence1: The average novel of 200,000 words for $25 works out at 8,000 words per dollar.
sentence1_translated: Ìwé kan tó ní ọ̀rọ̀ bíi 200,000 fún $25 máa ń ní ọ̀rọ̀ bíi 8,000 fún dọ́là kan.
